column4: whats the best way to run resize2fs to let linux allocate the new free space from a resize of the partition table?  from a bootdisk?  resize2fs can only be ran on an unmounted filesystem.
if it's not the root partition, you can do it fro myour regular system
if it is, getting the live cd is probably the simplest solution
can i do it from a floppy disk?
do you know how to construct a linux boot disk containing parted?
no. do you know where a tutorial is?
no, I'd really just go with a live cd of some sort
or even use the ubuntu installer itself
thats what i was going to do, but i don't have the disk with me
i don't know if i made this clear... the partition is already resized.  i just need to run resize2fs on it to let linux reallocate it
because you didn't tell it what filesystem it is
mount: /dev/fd0 is not a valid block device
mount: /dev/fd0 is not a valid block device
that means it thinks you don't have a floppy drive
perhaps the correct driver is't loaded
well i had just used it and thats what i don't understand
